events.event_name: Russia S&P Global Composite PMI Release (January 2026)
events.description: Russia’s S&P Global Composite PMI rose to 52.1 in January 2026, marking the highest level since January 2025.
A recent increase in the VAT rate in Russia which impacted cost burdens for manufacturers and service providers.

facts.fact_text: Russia’s S&P Global Composite PMI rose to 52.1 in January 2026 from 50.0 in December.

evidences.evidence_text: Russia’s S&P Global Composite PMI rose to 52.1 in January 2026 from 50.0 in December

facts.fact_text: New orders in Russia increased at the fastest pace in a year in January 2026.

evidences.evidence_text: New orders increased at the fastest pace in a year

facts.fact_text: Employment levels in Russia were broadly stable overall.

evidences.evidence_text: Employment levels were broadly stable overall.

facts.fact_text: The VAT rate increase led to a sharper rise in input costs and output charges compared with December.

evidences.evidence_text: a recent increase in the VAT rate pushed up cost burdens for both manufacturers and service providers, leading to a sharper rise in input costs and output charges compared with December

claims.claim_text: The rise in PMI signals a renewed expansion in private-sector activity.
claims.author: S&P Global

evidences.evidence_text: signaling a renewed expansion in private-sector activity

claims.claim_text: Business confidence improved due to expectations of stronger demand and improving operating conditions.

evidences.evidence_text: business confidence improved in manufacturing and services, supported by expectations of stronger demand and improving operating conditions

evidence.evidence_text: a recent increase in the VAT rate pushed up cost burdens for both manufacturers and service providers, leading to a sharper rise in input costs and output charges
Russia’s S&P Global Composite PMI rose to 52.1 in January 2026... signaling a renewed expansion in private-sector activity
Employment levels were broadly stable overall.
